Georgia O’Keeffe: A Life

The author presents a person who was both vulnerable and fierce, passionate and coolly withholding, sensuous yet oddly unsexual.

The New York Times Book Review

  • Publisher: University Press of New England
  • Publication Date: Oct 01, 1989
  • ISBN: 9780874519068
  • ISBN Digital: 0874519063
  • Barnes & Noble
  • Powells
  • Your Local Bookstore
  • Digital Editions
  • Apple iBooks
  • Barnes & Noble Nook

Georgia O’Keeffe is arguably the 20th century’s leading woman artist. Coming of age along with American modernism, her life was rich in intense relationships — with family, friends, and especially noted photographer Alfred Stieglitz. Her struggle between the rigorous demands of love and work resulted in extraordinary accomplishments. Her often-eroticized flowers, bones, stones, skulls, and pelvises became extremely well known to a broad American public. The New York Times Book Review named this richly detailed and moving biography a Notable Book of the Year.

This biography, the first to draw on sources unavailable during O’Keeffe’s lifetime—and the first to be granted her family’s cooperation—offers a persuasive feminist analysis of the life and work of an iconic figure in American art.

Publishers Weekly

[T]he first sensible discussion of how photography influenced O’Keeffe’s painting.

Ms. magazine

This is without question the best book ever written on O’Keeffe and an invaluable resource not only for scholars but for the general public. It is accurate, insightful, and beautifully written.

Calvin Tomkins, The New Yorker
